Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on Coagulation Management in Cardiothoracic Surgery

Trial_Design.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through a computer-generated sequence

Participants.evidence: Participants were eligible if they were scheduled for cardiothoracic surgery and met predefined criteria.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received tranexamic acid and heparin, along with nonpharmacological methods such as hemostatic agents, while the control group received standard care.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the reduction in postoperative bleeding, assessed over 24 hours.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was achieved through a computer-generated sequence, with allocation concealment via sealed envelopes.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: A total of 200 participants were randomised, with 100 assigned to each group, during the recruitment period from January 2020 to June 2021.

Number_Analysed.evidence: The analysis included 98 participants in the intervention group and 97 in the control group, following an intention-to-treat approach.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The intervention group experienced a significant reduction in postoperative bleeding (mean difference = 5.2 mL, 95% CI 3.1 to 7.3; p = 0.01).

Harms.evidence: Adverse events were observed in 3% of the intervention group and 1% of the control group, with mild gastrointestinal side-effects reported.
